UpdateSecurity.documentation: Updates the security settings for the cluster. You can use this operation to specify encryption and authentication on existing clusters.

ClusterArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the cluster to be updated.

SecretArnList.documentation: List of AWS Secrets Manager secret ARNs.

ClusterArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the cluster.

UnprocessedScramSecrets.documentation: List of errors when associating secrets to cluster.

BrokerAZDistribution.documentation:
The distribution of broker nodes across Availability Zones. This is an optional parameter. If you don't specify it, Amazon MSK gives it the value DEFAULT. You can also explicitly set this parameter to the value DEFAULT. No other values are currently allowed.

Amazon MSK distributes the broker nodes evenly across the Availability Zones that correspond to the subnets you provide when you create the cluster.

KafkaBrokerNodeId.documentation: The ID of the broker to update.

VolumeSizeGB.documentation: Size of the EBS volume to update.

BrokerEBSVolumeInfo.documentation: Specifies the EBS volume upgrade information. The broker identifier must be set to the keyword ALL. This means the changes apply to all the brokers in the cluster.

BrokerAZDistribution.documentation:
The distribution of broker nodes across Availability Zones. This is an optional parameter. If you don't specify it, Amazon MSK gives it the value DEFAULT. You can also explicitly set this parameter to the value DEFAULT. No other values are currently allowed.

Amazon MSK distributes the broker nodes evenly across the Availability Zones that correspond to the subnets you provide when you create the cluster.

ClientSubnets.documentation: The list of subnets to connect to in the client virtual private cloud (VPC). AWS creates elastic network interfaces inside these subnets. Client applications use elastic network interfaces to produce and consume data. Client subnets can't occupy the Availability Zone with ID use use1-az3.

InstanceType.documentation: The type of Amazon EC2 instances to use for Apache Kafka brokers. The following instance types are allowed: kafka.m5.large, kafka.m5.xlarge, kafka.m5.2xlarge, kafka.m5.4xlarge, kafka.m5.12xlarge, and kafka.m5.24xlarge.

SecurityGroups.documentation: The AWS security groups to associate with the elastic network interfaces in order to specify who can connect to and communicate with the Amazon MSK cluster. If you don't specify a security group, Amazon MSK uses the default security group associated with the VPC.

StorageInfo.documentation: Contains information about storage volumes attached to MSK broker nodes.

BrokerNodeGroupInfo.documentation: Describes the setup to be used for Apache Kafka broker nodes in the cluster.

AttachedENIId.documentation: The attached elastic network interface of the broker.

ClientSubnet.documentation: The client subnet to which this broker node belongs.

ClientVpcIpAddress.documentation: The virtual private cloud (VPC) of the client.

CurrentBrokerSoftwareInfo.documentation: Information about the version of software currently deployed on the Apache Kafka brokers in the cluster.

ConfigurationArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the configuration used for the cluster. This field isn't visible in this preview release.

ConfigurationRevision.documentation: The revision of the configuration to use. This field isn't visible in this preview release.

BrokerSoftwareInfo.documentation: Information about the current software installed on the cluster.

Unauthenticated.documentation: Contains information about unauthenticated traffic to the cluster.

ClusterArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) that uniquely identifies the cluster.

CreationTime.documentation: The time when the cluster was created.

CurrentBrokerSoftwareInfo.documentation: Information about the version of software currently deployed on the Apache Kafka brokers in the cluster.

CurrentVersion.documentation: The current version of the MSK cluster.

EnhancedMonitoring.documentation: Specifies which metrics are gathered for the MSK cluster. This property has the following possible values: DEFAULT, PER_BROKER, PER_TOPIC_PER_BROKER, and PER_TOPIC_PER_PARTITION. For a list of the metrics associated with each of these levels of monitoring, see Monitoring.

NumberOfBrokerNodes.documentation: The number of broker nodes in the cluster.

State.documentation: The state of the cluster. The possible states are ACTIVE, CREATING, DELETING, FAILED, HEALING, MAINTENANCE, REBOOTING_BROKER, and UPDATING.

ZookeeperConnectString.documentation: The connection string to use to connect to the Apache ZooKeeper cluster.

ZookeeperConnectStringTls.documentation: The connection string to use to connect to zookeeper cluster on Tls port.

ActiveOperationArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) that uniquely identifies a cluster operation.

ClusterArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) that uniquely identifies the cluster.

CreationTime.documentation: The time when the cluster was created.

CurrentVersion.documentation: The current version of the MSK cluster.

State.documentation: The state of the cluster. The possible states are ACTIVE, CREATING, DELETING, FAILED, HEALING, MAINTENANCE, REBOOTING_BROKER, and UPDATING.

StateInfo.documentation: State Info for the Amazon MSK cluster.

ClientRequestId.documentation: The ID of the API request that triggered this operation.

ClusterArn.documentation: ARN of the cluster.

CreationTime.documentation: The time that the operation was created.

EndTime.documentation: The time at which the operation finished.

ErrorInfo.documentation: Describes the error if the operation fails.

SourceClusterInfo.documentation: Information about cluster attributes before a cluster is updated.

TargetClusterInfo.documentation: Information about cluster attributes after a cluster is updated.

StepInfo.documentation: Information about the step and its status.

ClusterState.documentation: The state of the Apache Kafka cluster.

ConfigurationInfo.documentation: Represents the configuration that you want Amazon MSK to use for the brokers in a cluster.

EnhancedMonitoring.documentation: Specifies the level of monitoring for the MSK cluster. The possible values are DEFAULT, PER_BROKER, PER_TOPIC_PER_BROKER, and PER_TOPIC_PER_PARTITION.

KafkaVersion.documentation: The Apache Kafka version that you want for the cluster.

NumberOfBrokerNodes.documentation: The number of broker nodes in the cluster.

CurrentBrokerSoftwareInfo.documentation: Information about the Apache Kafka version deployed on the brokers.

EnhancedMonitoring.documentation: Specifies the level of monitoring for the MSK cluster. The possible values are DEFAULT, PER_BROKER, PER_TOPIC_PER_BROKER, and PER_TOPIC_PER_PARTITION.

NumberOfBrokerNodes.documentation: The number of broker nodes in the cluster.

ZookeeperConnectString.documentation: The connection string to use to connect to the Apache ZooKeeper cluster.

ZookeeperConnectStringTls.documentation: The connection string to use to connect to the Apache ZooKeeper cluster on a TLS port.

VpcConfig.documentation: The configuration of the Amazon VPCs for the cluster.

SubnetIds.documentation: The IDs of the subnets associated with the cluster.

SecurityGroupIds.documentation: The IDs of the security groups associated with the cluster.

VpcConfigs.documentation: The configuration of the Amazon VPCs for the cluster.
The configuration of the Amazon VPCs for the cluster.

CompatibleKafkaVersion.documentation: Contains source Apache Kafka versions and compatible target Apache Kafka versions.

Arn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the configuration.

CreationTime.documentation: The time when the configuration was created.

KafkaVersions.documentation: An array of the versions of Apache Kafka with which you can use this MSK configuration. You can use this configuration for an MSK cluster only if the Apache Kafka version specified for the cluster appears in this array.

State.documentation: The state of the configuration. The possible states are ACTIVE, DELETING, and DELETE_FAILED.

Revision.documentation: The revision of the configuration to use.

ConfigurationInfo.documentation: Specifies the configuration to use for the brokers.

CreationTime.documentation: The time when the configuration revision was created.

Tags.documentation: A map of tags that you want the cluster to have.

BrokerNodeGroupInfo.documentation: Information about the broker nodes in the cluster.

ConfigurationInfo.documentation: Represents the configuration that you want MSK to use for the brokers in a cluster.

EnhancedMonitoring.documentation: Specifies the level of monitoring for the MSK cluster. The possible values are DEFAULT, PER_BROKER, PER_TOPIC_PER_BROKER, and PER_TOPIC_PER_PARTITION.

NumberOfBrokerNodes.documentation: The number of broker nodes in the cluster.

ClusterArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the cluster.

State.documentation: The state of the cluster. The possible states are ACTIVE, CREATING, DELETING, FAILED, HEALING, MAINTENANCE, REBOOTING_BROKER, and UPDATING.

ClusterArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the cluster.

State.documentation: The state of the cluster. The possible states are ACTIVE, CREATING, DELETING, FAILED, HEALING, MAINTENANCE, REBOOTING_BROKER, and UPDATING.

ClusterType.documentation: The type of the cluster. The possible states are PROVISIONED or SERVERLESS.

KafkaVersions.documentation: The versions of Apache Kafka with which you can use this MSK configuration.

ServerProperties.documentation: Contents of the server.properties file. When using the API, you must ensure that the contents of the file are base64 encoded. When using the AWS Management Console, the SDK, or the AWS CLI, the contents of server.properties can be in plaintext.

Arn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the configuration.

CreationTime.documentation: The time when the configuration was created.

State.documentation: The state of the configuration. The possible states are ACTIVE, DELETING, and DELETE_FAILED.

ClusterArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) that uniquely identifies the cluster.

CurrentVersion.documentation: The current version of the MSK cluster.

ClusterArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the cluster.

State.documentation: The state of the cluster. The possible states are ACTIVE, CREATING, DELETING, FAILED, HEALING, MAINTENANCE, REBOOTING_BROKER, and UPDATING.

Arn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) that uniquely identifies an MSK configuration.
The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) that uniquely identifies an MSK configuration.

State.documentation: The state of the configuration. The possible states are ACTIVE, DELETING, and DELETE_FAILED.

ClusterOperationArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) that uniquely identifies the MSK cluster operation.

ClusterArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) that uniquely identifies the cluster.
The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) that uniquely identifies the cluster.

Arn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) that uniquely identifies an MSK configuration and all of its revisions.
The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the configuration.

CreationTime.documentation: The time when the configuration was created.

KafkaVersions.documentation: The versions of Apache Kafka with which you can use this MSK configuration.

State.documentation: The state of the configuration. The possible states are ACTIVE, DELETING, and DELETE_FAILED.

Arn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) that uniquely identifies an MSK configuration and all of its revisions.

Revision.documentation: A string that uniquely identifies a revision of an MSK configuration.

Arn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the configuration.

CreationTime.documentation: The time when the configuration was created.

ServerProperties.documentation: Contents of the server.properties file. When using the API, you must ensure that the contents of the file are base64 encoded. When using the AWS Management Console, the SDK, or the AWS CLI, the contents of server.properties can be in plaintext.

ClusterArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the cluster to be updated.

SecretArnList.documentation: List of AWS Secrets Manager secret ARNs.

ClusterArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the cluster.

UnprocessedScramSecrets.documentation: List of errors when disassociating secrets to cluster.

VolumeSize.documentation: The size in GiB of the EBS volume for the data drive on each broker node.

EBSStorageInfo.documentation: Contains information about the EBS storage volumes attached to Apache Kafka broker nodes.

DataVolumeKMSKeyId.documentation: The ARN of the AWS KMS key for encrypting data at rest. If you don't specify a KMS key, MSK creates one for you and uses it.

ClientBroker.documentation:
Indicates the encryption setting for data in transit between clients and brokers. The following are the possible values.

TLS means that client-broker communication is enabled with TLS only.

TLS_PLAINTEXT means that client-broker communication is enabled for both TLS-encrypted, as well as plaintext data.

PLAINTEXT means that client-broker communication is enabled in plaintext only.

The default value is TLS_PLAINTEXT.

InCluster.documentation:
When set to true, it indicates that data communication among the broker nodes of the cluster is encrypted. When set to false, the communication happens in plaintext.

The default value is true.

EncryptionInTransit.documentation: The settings for encrypting data in transit.

EncryptionInfo.documentation: Includes encryption-related information, such as the AWS KMS key used for encrypting data at rest and whether you want MSK to encrypt your data in transit.

EnhancedMonitoring.documentation: Specifies which metrics are gathered for the MSK cluster. This property has the following possible values: DEFAULT, PER_BROKER, PER_TOPIC_PER_BROKER, and PER_TOPIC_PER_PARTITION. For a list of the metrics associated with each of these levels of monitoring, see Monitoring.

ErrorString.documentation: An optional field to provide more details about the error.

ErrorInfo.documentation: Returns information about an error state of the cluster.

ClusterArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) that uniquely identifies the cluster.

BootstrapBrokerString.documentation: A string containing one or more hostname:port pairs.

BootstrapBrokerStringTls.documentation: A string containing one or more DNS names (or IP) and TLS port pairs.

BootstrapBrokerStringSaslScram.documentation: A string containing one or more DNS names (or IP) and Sasl Scram port pairs.

BootstrapBrokerStringSaslIam.documentation: A string that contains one or more DNS names (or IP addresses) and SASL IAM port pairs.

BootstrapBrokerStringPublicTls.documentation: A string containing one or more DNS names (or IP) and TLS port pairs.

BootstrapBrokerStringPublicSaslScram.documentation: A string containing one or more DNS names (or IP) and Sasl Scram port pairs.

BootstrapBrokerStringPublicSaslIam.documentation: A string that contains one or more DNS names (or IP addresses) and SASL IAM port pairs.

ClusterArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the cluster check.
The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) that uniquely identifies the cluster.

MaxResults.documentation: The maximum number of results to return in the response. If there are more results, the response includes a NextToken parameter.

NextToken.documentation: The paginated results marker. When the result of the operation is truncated, the call returns NextToken in the response. To get the next batch, provide this token in your next request.

ClusterOperationInfoList.documentation: An array of cluster operation information objects.

NextToken.documentation: If the response of ListClusterOperations is truncated, it returns a NextToken in the response. This Nexttoken should be sent in the subsequent request to ListClusterOperations.

ClusterNameFilter.documentation: Specify a prefix of the name of the clusters that you want to list. The service lists all the clusters whose names start with this prefix.

MaxResults.documentation: The maximum number of results to return in the response. If there are more results, the response includes a NextToken parameter.

NextToken.documentation: The paginated results marker. When the result of the operation is truncated, the call returns NextToken in the response. To get the next batch, provide this token in your next request.

ClusterNameFilter.documentation: Specify a prefix of the names of the clusters that you want to list. The service lists all the clusters whose names start with this prefix.

ClusterInfoList.documentation: Information on each of the MSK clusters in the response.

Tags.documentation: The key-value pair for the resource tag.

BrokerEBSVolumeInfo.documentation: Specifies the size of the EBS volume and the ID of the associated broker.

ConfigurationInfo.documentation: Information about the changes in the configuration of the brokers.

NumberOfBrokerNodes.documentation: The number of broker nodes in the cluster.

EnhancedMonitoring.documentation: Specifies which Apache Kafka metrics Amazon MSK gathers and sends to Amazon CloudWatch for this cluster.

LoggingInfo.documentation: You can configure your MSK cluster to send broker logs to different destination types. This is a container for the configuration details related to broker logs.

InstanceType.documentation: Information about the Amazon MSK broker type.

MutableClusterInfo.documentation: Information about cluster attributes that can be updated via update APIs.

EnabledInBroker.documentation: Indicates whether you want to turn on or turn off the Node Exporter.

NodeExporter.documentation: Indicates whether you want to turn on or turn off the Node Exporter.

JmxExporter.documentation: Indicates whether you want to turn on or turn off the JMX Exporter.

NodeExporter.documentation: Indicates whether you want to turn on or turn off the Node Exporter.

Enabled.documentation: Provisioned throughput is enabled or not.

VolumeThroughput.documentation: Throughput value of the EBS volumes for the data drive on each kafka broker node in MiB per second.

ProvisionedThroughput.documentation: Contains information about provisioned throughput for EBS storage volumes attached to kafka broker nodes.

Type.documentation: The value DISABLED indicates that public access is turned off. SERVICE_PROVIDED_EIPS indicates that public access is turned on.

BrokerIds.documentation: The list of broker IDs to be rebooted. The reboot-broker operation supports rebooting one broker at a time.

ClusterArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the cluster to be updated.

Iam.documentation: Indicates whether IAM access control is enabled.

StorageInfo.documentation: Contains information about storage volumes attached to MSK broker nodes.

Tags.documentation: The key-value pair for the resource tag.

Enabled.documentation: Specifies whether you want to turn on or turn off TLS authentication.
Specifies whether you want to turn on or turn off unauthenticated traffic to your cluster.

UnprocessedScramSecret.documentation: Error info for scram secret associate/disassociate failure.

ResourceArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) that uniquely identifies the resource that's associated with the tags.

TagKeys.documentation:
Tag keys must be unique for a given cluster. In addition, the following restrictions apply:

  • Each tag key must be unique. If you add a tag with a key that's already in use, your new tag overwrites the existing key-value pair.

  • You can't start a tag key with aws: because this prefix is reserved for use by AWS. AWS creates tags that begin with this prefix on your behalf, but you can't edit or delete them.

  • Tag keys must be between 1 and 128 Unicode characters in length.

  • Tag keys must consist of the following characters: Unicode letters, digits, white space, and the following special characters: _ . / = + - @.

ServerProperties.documentation: Contents of the server.properties file. When using the API, you must ensure that the contents of the file are base64 encoded. When using the AWS Management Console, the SDK, or the AWS CLI, the contents of server.properties can be in plaintext.
